title: 110_hr4308
content: The Act may be cited as the "NASA Innovation Fund and Sponsorship Act of 2007". It includes a section on the NASA Innovation Fund. The "NASA Innovation Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States, funded by charitable donations or program proceeds. The Fund can be used for advertising purposes, limited to 10% of transfers per fiscal year, not exceeding $1,000,000. The NASA Innovation Fund allows for transfers up to $1,000,000 per fiscal year for advertising and $200,000 for administering prize competitions. Any remaining amounts can be used for prizes under section 314 of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958. The Secretary of the Treasury can invest excess Fund amounts not needed for current withdrawals. The Secretary of the Treasury can invest excess NASA Innovation Fund amounts in interest-bearing obligations of the United States, either on original issue or by purchasing outstanding obligations at market price. The Fund's obligations can be sold at market price, with interest and proceeds credited back to the Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury can sell obligations acquired by the Fund at market price, with interest and proceeds credited back to the Fund. NASA INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The NASA Innovation Fund Sponsorship Advisory Committee is established within NASA to advise on program implementation. The committee consists of 5 US citizens with expertise in education and promotional activities, appointed by the Administrator. The Chair and Vice Chair are also appointed by the Administrator. The Administrator appoints individuals from academia, the nonprofit sector, and the private sector to the Advisory Committee. Members serve three-year staggered terms, with vacancies filled by the Administrator for the remainder of the term. The Advisory Committee members are appointed by the Administrator and serve three-year staggered terms. If a member leaves before their term ends, a successor can be appointed to serve the remainder of the term. Members cannot serve on the committee for more than 6 years. They are not compensated for their services but are reimbursed for necessary expenses. The committee must meet regularly. The Advisory Committee members are reimbursed for traveling and subsistence expenses. The committee must meet at least 4 times a year, with the Administrator and Chief of Strategic Communications of NASA or their designees present to provide guidance. Additional meetings may be called by the Administrator. SEC. 4. INNOVATION FUND SPONSORSHIP PROGRAM. The Administrator is authorized to create an Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program allowing individuals to use the Partnership Logo in exchange for a monetary contribution. A person approved for the program is known as a "sponsor". The logo will include the words "NASA Innovation Fund Partner" based on Advisory Committee recommendations. The Administrator will select a logo for sponsors based on Advisory Committee recommendations. Sponsors must submit an application with contribution amount and promotional program details using the Partnership Logo. Sponsors must submit an application to the Administrator with the contribution amount and a detailed promotional program using the Partnership Logo. The program should focus on educational information, promoting STEM programs, or highlighting employment and educational opportunities in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The sponsorship agreement requires approved applicants to provide a specified amount and allows them to use the Partnership Logo in their promotional programs. Restrictions for the program include not including certain elements. Restrictions for the promotional program include no logos on spacecraft, no astronaut endorsements, no agency-wide endorsements, no in-kind contributions, and a minimum level of contribution. The Administrator establishes restrictions for the promotional program, including no logos on spacecraft, no astronaut or agency-wide endorsements, no in-kind contributions, and a minimum level of contribution. Additionally, procedures are set up to protect proprietary information submitted. Congress encourages NASA to participate in authorized activities and assist sponsors. Congress strongly encourages NASA to participate in authorized activities and provide assistance to sponsors for promotional programs. Unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo may result in civil action by the Administrator. The Administrator may take civil action for preventive relief against unauthorized use of the Partnership Logo, with penalties of $100,000 per violation. Any amounts received will be transferred to the Fund. Additionally, sponsors implementing non-compliant promotional programs may face similar legal actions. The Administrator can take civil action for preventive relief, such as injunctions or restraining orders. A report must be submitted to Congress annually, detailing NASA's actions, receipts, expenditures, and the efficiency of the Innovation Fund Sponsorship Program. The Advisory Committee must also report on its actions each year. The Advisory Committee consults with NASA Centers annually to improve the program authorized under this section and section 4. SEC. 5 amends section 314(i) of the National Aeronautics and Space Act of 1958. SEC. 6 defines key terms like Administrator, NASA, Partnership Logo, and Promotional program.
